text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 21.4.3, Refund Inquiries, Returned Refunds/Releases.
IRM 21.4.3.5.3(4) (a) Updated to incorporate EIP 3 information, and removed requirement to send Form 8822 to Refund Inquiry when S- freeze is present. IPU 21U1338 issued 12-13-2021.
IRM 21.4.3.5.5(4) Changed verbiage to include EIP 3 in returned Economic Impact Payments. Change made for IRM accuracy.
Editorial changes made throughout the IRM for clarity and updated plain language, grammar, web addresses, IRM and legal references.
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 21.4.3, Returned Refunds/Releases, dated 09-10-2021, (effective 10-01-2021) is superseded. This IRM also incorporates the following IRM Procedural Updates (IPUs): IPU 21U1338 (dated 12-13-2021) and IPU 22U0343 (dated 03-07-2022).
AUDIENCE
Employees located in all business operating divisions who have contact with taxpayers either on the by correspondence, or personal contact
Table of Contents

) Purpose: This IRM provides instructions and procedures for all Customer Service Representatives and Taxpayer Assistance Center functions who and address various returned refunds and refund releases in performance of daily duties. (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are all refund inquiry examiners, customer service representatives and taxpayer assistance center (TAC) employees in W&I and SB/SE. (
) Policy Owner: Director of Accounts Management is the policy owner of this IRM. (
) Program Owner: Accounts Management Policy and Procedures IMF (PPI), the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are organizations with Accounts Management collaborates (e.g., Return Integrity and Compliance Services (RICS) and Submission Processing). (

) Program Goals: Program goals for this type of work are: • Achieve a high customer accuracy rate for phone calls and paper ad- justments related to Refund Inquiries • Efficiency in resolving paper adjustment cases related to Refund Inquiries • Continuous assessment for program vulnerabilities and opportunities improvement. • Effective communication with customers. The Accounts Management Program Letter on the AM website has more mation on these goals. A copy of the Accounts Management Program Letter also in IRM
, Accounts Management Guide for Managers. (
) Employees in the Accounts Management (AM) organization respond to taxpayer inquiries, phone calls, process claims and other internal adjustment request related to Returned Refunds/Releases. (

) Refund checks issued to taxpayers may be returned to the IRS or Regional Financial Center (RFC) for many reasons. This section of the IRM provides information and instructions for processing returned refund checks. Caution: Before discussing any tax information, you must be sure you are speaking with the taxpayer or authorized representative. See IRM
, General Disclosure Guidelines. Before leaving any message a taxpayer’s answering machine, review IRM
, Methods for munication of Conﬁdential Information. Fax procedures contained in
, Faxing, must be reviewed prior to faxing conﬁdential mation to the taxpayer. (

) Refund checks are returned for several reasons. Some of the most common are: • Incorrect address, U. S. Postal Service was unable to deliver check. • The taxpayer is not entitled to a refund. • The credit that created the refund belongs on another module. • The check is issued in the wrong name. • The check cannot be negotiated (joint/deceased taxpayer). • The check is expired and cannot be cashed (older than
months). (
) The Receipt and Control (R&C) function within a Campus receives the returned refund checks and directs them to the Campus Refund Inquiry (RI) Unit. (

) Returned refund checks must be stamped or written “non-negotiable” on the front of the check, or have the word “void” stamped or written on the front back of the check. At the time of receipt, the employee should stamp “void” the returned check. (

) Refund checks returned to a Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC) must be forwarded to the issuing campus Refund Inquiry Unit, in the proper business operating division (BOD) for processing. The issuing campus location is on front, at the bottom of the check, and displays all or the ﬁrst six letters of campus. Individual Master File (IMF) returned checks will be worked at IMF campuses and Business Master File (BMF) will be worked at BMF For fax numbers and addresses, see Refund Inquiry Unit Addresses, on Servicewide Electronic Research Program (SERP) under the Who/Where Internal Revenue Manual

At the time of receipt, the employee should stamp the returned check. The issuing campus location is front, at the bottom of the check, and displays all or the ﬁrst six letters of campus. Returned refund checks must be worked by campuses in the proper Business Operating Division (BOD). Individual Master File (IMF) returned checks will be worked at IMF campuses and BMF will be worked at BMF campuses. Send misrouted cases to the proper campus.
Note: If a case involves both IMF and BMF returned checks, the receiving campus must coordinate case actions with the proper Refund Inquiry team.

) Taxpayer identiﬁcation numbers (TINs) are no longer printed on refund checks. If a refund check is received without a TIN, research command code (CC) IMFOLC or CC BMFOLC using the check number and symbol located on the check in the upper right-hand corner. CC IMFOLC and CC BMFOLC will search for the matching tax module and return the correct CC IMFOLT or CC BMFOLT screen. Since CC IMFOL and CC BMFOL will only try to access the valid TIN, be sure to compare the check with the tax module to ensure you have the correct module. See IRM
